body:
We'll look into this for ORT 1.12. I'm not so familiar with the Python API (vs C++), but I know we've been able to call other models fine via the Python API twice, albeit not via this `io_binding` ðŸ¤”. One example is squeezenet below which executes twice and prints:

```
Max result: 285
Max result: 184
```

From imagenet_categories.txt:
Egyptian cat
Irish terrier

```
import onnxruntime as ort
import numpy
import numpy.random

from PIL import Image, ImageOps

image_file_path = "Cat_023-FF.png"
image_file_path2 = "puppy.png"

def infer_using_ort_filepath(model_file_path):
    image = Image.open(image_file_path)
    image = ImageOps.fit(image, (224, 224), method = 0, bleed = 0, centering = (0.5, 0.5))
    image_tensor = numpy.array(image, numpy.float32)
    image_tensor = numpy.transpose(image_tensor, axes=[2,0,1])
    image_tensor = image_tensor.reshape([1,3,224,224])
    #image_tensor = numpy.random.random((1, 3, 224, 224), dtype=numpy.float32)

    ep_list = ['DmlExecutionProvider'] # 'CPUExecutionProvider', 'CUDAExecutionProvider'...
    session_options = ort.SessionOptions()
    session_options.enable_mem_pattern = False

    session = ort.InferenceSession(model_file_path, session_options, providers=ep_list)

    input_name = session.get_inputs()[0].name
    print("input name", input_name)
    input_shape = session.get_inputs()[0].shape
    print("input shape", input_shape)
    input_type = session.get_inputs()[0].type
    print("input type", input_type)

    output_name = session.get_outputs()[0].name
    print("output name", output_name)
    output_shape = session.get_outputs()[0].shape
    print("output shape", output_shape)
    output_type = session.get_outputs()[0].type
    print("output type", output_type)

    # Predict 1st image content.
    result = session.run([output_name], {input_name: image_tensor})
    print(result)
    print("Max result:", numpy.argmax(result))

    # Predict 2nd image content.
    image = Image.open(image_file_path2)
    image = ImageOps.fit(image, (224, 224), method = 0, bleed = 0, centering = (0.5, 0.5))
    image_tensor = numpy.array(image, numpy.float32)
    image_tensor = numpy.transpose(image_tensor, axes=[2,0,1])
    image_tensor = image_tensor.reshape([1,3,224,224])

    result = session.run([output_name], {input_name: image_tensor})
    print("Max result:", numpy.argmax(result))

def infer_using_ort_dataset(model_name):
    from onnxruntime.datasets import get_example
    example_file_path = ort.datasets.get_example(model_name)
    return infer_using_ort_filepath(example_file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    infer_using_ort_filepath("squeezenet1.1-7.onnx")
```

Requirements.txt via `pip freeze`:

```
onnxruntime-directml==1.11.1
Pillow==7.2.0
numpy==1.21.6
```

@JiaPai12138 I'm unable to repro the issue - I get two distinct answers still after changing to use `io_binding` instead of the normal `session.run`. Can you try the code below locally to see your results?

```
import onnxruntime as ort
import numpy
import numpy.random

from PIL import Image, ImageOps

image_file_path = "Cat_023-FF.png"
image_file_path2 = "puppy.png"

def infer_using_ort_filepath(model_file_path):
    image = Image.open(image_file_path)
    image = ImageOps.fit(image, (224, 224), method = 0, bleed = 0, centering = (0.5, 0.5))
    image_tensor = numpy.array(image, numpy.float32)
    image_tensor = numpy.transpose(image_tensor, axes=[2,0,1])
    image_tensor = image_tensor.reshape([1,3,224,224])
    #image_tensor = numpy.random.random((1, 3, 224, 224), dtype=numpy.float32)

    ep_list = ['DmlExecutionProvider'] # 'CPUExecutionProvider', 'CUDAExecutionProvider'...
    session_options = ort.SessionOptions()
    session_options.enable_mem_pattern = False

    session = ort.InferenceSession(model_file_path, session_options, providers=ep_list)

    input_name = session.get_inputs()[0].name
    print("input name", input_name)
    input_shape = session.get_inputs()[0].shape
    print("input shape", input_shape)
    input_type = session.get_inputs()[0].type
    print("input type", input_type)

    output_name = session.get_outputs()[0].name
    print("output name", output_name)
    output_shape = session.get_outputs()[0].shape
    print("output shape", output_shape)
    output_type = session.get_outputs()[0].type
    print("output type", output_type)

    io_binding = session.io_binding()

    # Predict 1st image content.
    # disabled: result = session.run([output_name], {input_name: image_tensor})
    io_binding.bind_cpu_input('data', image_tensor)
    io_binding.bind_output('squeezenet0_flatten0_reshape0')
    session.run_with_iobinding(io_binding)
    result = io_binding.copy_outputs_to_cpu()[0]
    print(result)
    print("1st image max result:", numpy.argmax(result))

    # Predict 2nd image content.
    image = Image.open(image_file_path2)
    image = ImageOps.fit(image, (224, 224), method = 0, bleed = 0, centering = (0.5, 0.5))
    image_tensor = numpy.array(image, numpy.float32)
    image_tensor = numpy.transpose(image_tensor, axes=[2,0,1])
    image_tensor = image_tensor.reshape([1,3,224,224])

    # disabled: result = session.run([output_name], {input_name: image_tensor})
    io_binding.bind_cpu_input('data', image_tensor)
    io_binding.bind_output('squeezenet0_flatten0_reshape0')
    session.run_with_iobinding(io_binding)
    result = io_binding.copy_outputs_to_cpu()[0]

    print("2nd image max result:", numpy.argmax(result))

def infer_using_ort_dataset(model_name):
    from onnxruntime.datasets import get_example
    example_file_path = ort.datasets.get_example(model_name)
    return infer_using_ort_filepath(example_file_path)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    # From https://github.com/onnx/models/blob/main/vision/classification/squeezenet/model/squeezenet1.1-7.onnx
    infer_using_ort_filepath("squeezenet1.1-7.onnx")
```

![Cat_023-FF](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1809166/175752998-b8630b78-91c3-4cc5-a375-b5fb5c3baeb4.png)

![puppy](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1809166/175753019-f62e5916-047e-45ba-be1d-c7242902f95c.png)

So looks like i need to "rebind" cpu_input and output each time i got a new image instead of just change the 'image_tensor' value. I will do further try to see if it (iobind) benefits in inference time vs. without iobind

> instead of just change the 'image_tensor' value

I *believe* so ðŸ¤”, because otherwise ORT wouldn't know that the numpy-backed `image_tensor` has actually changed between executions. Reading the description of `bind_cpu_input` [here](https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/api/python/api_summary.html#data-on-device), a *copy* of the data is sent to the GPU. So if you just executed twice (without rebinding the new data), you're likely still getting the old GPU input data.

> 

I got you. Many thanks!
Also, does c++ have to do "rebind" process?

issue.title: C++ inference with IOBinding and DirectML

labels.name: ep:DML
labels.description: issues related to the DirectML execution provider

body: Many thanks for your answers! Really appreciate!
